title: Freedmen's Bureau Records: W. Storer How to Orlando Brown, August 8, 1865
summary: How's first report as Bureau Superintendent in Staunton sheds light on the early post-war situation of freed blacks. He writes that their new freedom seems tenuous as their former masters threaten to reestablish slavery once Union troops have left. How also notes that he has had trouble hiring military personnel to staff the office, and so has hired civilians.
keywords: Administration/Bureaucracy, Education, Employment/Labor, Military Authority, Patriotism, Race Relations, Slavery, American Civil War
